title: 103_hr1642
content: The Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 1993 allows for the rescission of specific items in legislation. The President may rescind discretionary budget authority for fiscal years 1994 or 1995 under certain conditions, as outlined in The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The President can rescind discretionary budget authority for fiscal years 1994 or 1995 under specific conditions outlined in The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The President must notify Congress of the rescission within twenty calendar days after the enactment of an appropriations act for the respective fiscal year. Each appropriations bill requires a separate rescission message. The President can rescind discretionary budget authority for fiscal years 1994 or 1995 under specific conditions outlined in The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Each appropriations bill requires a separate rescission message. The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 allows the President to rescind budget authority under specific conditions. A rescission disapproval bill must be enacted within a specified timeframe to prevent the cancellation of the rescinded amount. The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 allows the President to rescind budget authority under specific conditions. If a special message is transmitted by the President and the Congress adjourns before the expiration of the review period, the rescission shall not take effect. The message is deemed retransmitted in the next Congress, and the review period starts from the first day of the new Congress. The Act defines "rescission disapproval bill" as a bill disapproving a rescission of discretionary budget authority for fiscal year 1994 or 1995. "Calendar days of session" are defined as days when both Houses of Congress are in session. Whenever the President rescinds budget authority, a special message must be sent to Congress detailing the amount, where the authority is available, reasons for the rescission, estimated effects, and all relevant factors. The President must send a special message to Congress when rescinding budget authority, detailing the amount, reasons, estimated effects, and relevant factors. The message must be transmitted to both the House of Representatives and the Senate on the same day, referred to the appropriate committees, and printed in the Federal Register. The rescission disapproval bill introduced with respect to a special message shall be referred to the appropriate committees of the House of Representatives or the Senate. Any rescission disapproval bill received in the Senate from the House shall be considered in the Senate, with debate limited to ten hours divided between the majority and minority leaders or their designees. Debate in the Senate on debatable motions or appeals regarding a bill is limited to one hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. The minority leader can control time in opposition. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders. Motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit is not in order. In the Senate or House of Representatives, it is not allowed to consider any rescission disapproval bill that is not related to the budget authority transmitted by the President. Amendments to a rescission disapproval bill are also not permitted. These restrictions can be waived in the Senate with a three-fifths majority vote.
